newsitem.title: USA: ATHLETICS-CLUTCH JUMP GIVES HOWARD NCAA LONG JUMP TITLE.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-CLUTCH JUMP GIVES HOWARD NCAA LONG JUMP TITLE.

text.p: U.S. Olympian Robert Howard, in danger of being eliminated, used a clutch third attempt to win the men's long jump at the U.S. collegiate championships on Thursday.

The winning leap of 8.21 meters (26 feet, 11 1/4 inches), was inferior to Howard's seasonal best of 8.40 metres (27 feet, 6 3/4 inches) -- the second best jump in the world this year -- but it brought instant elation to the University of Arkansas student, who finished eighth in the triple jump at the Atlanta Olympics.
He quickly thrust both arms in the air after hearing the winning mark, which came on his last attempt in the preliminary round of three jumps.
Before the jump he had been tied for ninth in the competition and risked elimination had he not improved.
He had jumped only 7.56 metres (24 feet, 9 3/4 inches) on his first attempt and fouled on his second jump.
He did not improve in the finals, passing one attempt and then jumping 7.53 (24 feet 8 1/2 inches) and 7.95 (26 feet 1 inch). But his final preliminary jump held up.
American Ivan Wagner, a second-year student at the University of Texas, surprised the men's high jump field with a leap of 2.30 meters (7 feet, 6 1/2 inches) to win by 11 centimetres (4 1/4 inches).
Tressa Thompson, who had always dreamed of playing football for the University of Nebraska, won a national championship for her school in another sport.
The former high school tight end won the women's shot put with a throw of 18.50 meters (60 feet, 8 1/2 inches).
She said her mother made her give up football because of the contact involved in the sport.
"But football gave me the aggressiveness that has carried me through all my sports," said Thompson.
